The thing that really sucks about this is that the longer a virus has a chance to hang around the longer it has a chance to evolve and change. My education is more geared toward equine biosecurity/farm biosecurity, but it still applies to humans. There was an outbreak of foot and mouth disease in 2001 in the UK. What was specifically troubling about this outbreak was that it went airborne, it changed and was devastating in terms of its effect economically. This can happen with any virus as they are living things. So when you have something like this, where a disease was almost eradicated, it really exemplifies just how stupid anti-vaxxers are and the potential they have for damage.

Anti-vaccination proponents hold a special place in the list of things I hate. I will not humor them, I will not even allow myself to get along with them, no matter how they act. Allow me to tell a story to explain why.

It was 2010, during the H1N1 Swine Flu pandemic, I was in 5th grade, and I had not yet gotten my yearly flu vaccine. My parents didn’t oppose it at all to be clear, I have amazing parents, we just hadn’t gotten around to it. But all my friends had gotten it, and had spent a lot of time around me, yet they never got sick. It was a normal Friday, I felt great, and I went about my day like nothing was wrong. We had a pizza party for lunch. I was in line to get my pizza and had just grabbed a slice. Then, with no warning, no nausea, no nothing, I suddenly began vomiting onto the floor. Naturally I was sent home for the day. Luckily it was Friday so I’d have the weekend to recover and I’d be back to school on Monday.

That was the idea at least, but instead my condition began to get progressively worse. I spent the entire weekend on an air mattress in my parents bedroom so they could keep an eye on me, I could barely stand up, and the entire weekend was nothing but the most horrific, unrelenting nausea I’d ever felt. My temperature reached 107 F. By Monday morning it was clear that I was not recovering. And my mom took me to the doctor. The doctor took one look at me and immediately decided that not only did I need to go to the hospital, she insisted I be taken by ambulance. So I was. I was put on a stretcher and sent off. I spent 5 days there, and felt like death the entire time. I had developed severe pneumonia in my lungs. And I felt so horrible that I remember I had to be taken to the X-ray room by wheelchair, and standing up for the X-ray was so painful I was crying. Two nurses had to hold me up by my arms over their shoulders in order for me to be able to stand. My blood oxygen concentration was extremely low. According to my doctors, the readers they used to measure it would rate a healthy person at 95-100, and anything below 90 was considered low. Even with an oxygen mask, I frequently dipped into the 70s and even the high 60s a couple times. I slowly recovered, and after 5 days was finally sent home, I was still weak and needed antibiotics for the pneumonia, so that kept me home, all in all I missed nearly a month of school. And at the time I had no idea just how bad my situation was, or how close I might have been to dying. And I would have, if not for modern medicine. Those doctors saved my life, they saved me from a flu strain that not even 100 years earlier at that time, had killed 50-100 million people.

I had not gotten my vaccine yet, and the doctors who saved my life told me that the vaccine would have prevented it. I trust them more than some paranoid parents spewing crap on the internet. This happened because I wasn’t vaccinated. And the idea that some children could be subjected to what I experienced, all because their self righteous parents think they know better than the ones who saved my life, pisses me off more than nearly anything else on this planet.

I am not like a lot of people, I have a very optimistic view of humanity, I do my best to break the negativity bias and show all the good we do as a species, and that we are better than we give ourselves credit for... But that doesn’t mean that there aren’t people who will do the opposite out of sheer ignorance, and those people need to be educated, or ignored.

The problem with the idiot anti-vaxxer thing is that there is a kernel of truth to some of it, and scientists and doctors have been very dismissive. Some vaccines really aren't necessary (just useful for some people) but the medical and science establishments usually act as though not getting every vaccine makes one a monster. And vaccines can and do hurt people, and I wish that doctors and scientists would be better about admitting that. Also, I think the vaccine schedule needs to be adjusted; we dump a crapton of vaccines into young kids rather rapidly, and I can see how that would be a problem. But the anti-vaxxers need to grow some brains and admit that some vaccines are absolutely critical, that the damage occasionally caused by vaccines is as much a part of them as the risk of being in an accident is a part of driving, and they really need to shut up about autism.

I think the anti-vaxxer "movement" would be far smaller if doctors and such admitted from the beginning that it's not true that all vaccines are necessary and don't have any downsides. I get why they didn't, but it has hurt their credibility and allowed the idiots to multiply.

Has anyone old enough to have gone through ALL (or nearly all) the diseases that children are vaccinated against? I’m only 61, but as a child, I had measles, mumps, chicken pox, rubella (German measles). They are ALL painful. When measles struck, my parents kept rooms darkened to protect our eyes from the sun, calamine lotion to ease the itching, and cool baths or cold compresses and baby aspirin (called low dose now) to control rising fevers. It was not uncommon for body temperatures to rise past 103 to 105 degrees or more, causing the sickest children to have seizures and brain damage.

The DTP (diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis) vaccine was available. I remember when the polio vaccine became widely available in the early 1960’s. Too many families had lost members or had become crippled from being infected during outbreaks in the prior dozen years. It was such a public health concern that mass immunizations took place, with whole families lining up in the city’s school gyms and community centers to be vaccinated. BTW, prior to the introduction of the measles vaccination, there was an average of 483 people who died EVERY year from measles - in the USA! Through widespread vaccination and herd immunity, measles had been eliminated from the USA sometime after 2002. Not now.....it is back, partially due to the anti-vaxers and partially due to rapid spread of infectious diseases via worldwide air travel.

A teacher was teaching the class new words and how to use them in a sentence.

"Daisy, use the word 'ambitious' in a sentence"
"My uncle is so ambitious he started his own business and now has 20 employees"

"Very good Daisy. Michael, use the word 'concentrate' in a sentence".
"If I don't concentrate during lessons the teacher be upset with me"

"Very good Michael. Now can anyone use the word 'contagious' in a sentence?"

Only one student had their hand raised, and it was Billy, known for being very naughty. The teacher asked the class again, but only Billy had his hand up. The teacher relented.

"Ok Billy, what's your sentence?"
"My Dad and I drive past a truck driver picking up oranges he lost from his load on the way to school. My Dad said that's gonna take that contagious!"

While certainly pro-vaccine, I do not think the concerns of anti-vaxers should be ignored, at least, those concerns that have merit.

For example, it was a major concern years ago that vaccines contained mercury, which is poisonous. Those concerns were heeded by the CDC, and mercury was removed from most (not all) vaccines. However, most third-world vaccines still contain dangerously high levels of mercury. Obviously, the solution is not to stop vaccinating, but to make efforts to produce safer vaccines.

Of course, there is the ever-present "autism link", which has been countered by subsequent studies. At the time, it seemed to be a legitimate concern, but upon further examination it was determined that there was likely no link. While many individuals still hold that concern, most scientists have concluded against it.

My point is, it helps no one to make fun of or denigrate those who present concerns about vaccines. Some concerns are legitimate should be incorporated into the effort to eradicate these diseases, instead of summarily condemning and mocking those who voice their concerns. Such attitudes have no place in the scientific community.

So I've been listening to the Tangents podcast without realizing there's a "butt" section that follows the end of the credits at the end of the show. The show ends, Hank reads the credits, and I naturally switch to a different podcast thinking it was the end of the show. Except today, I was listening while hauling groceries up to my apartment. Hands were tied holding grocery bags when Tangents ended and I suddenly hear this weird "butt" fact on coffee beans. You make my day a little brighter and a little cheekier.
